Award.AwardTitle: Paths to Bronze Age Complexity: Monitoring the Rise of Pecica "Santul Mare"

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With National Science Foundation Support, Dr. John O'Shea and an international team of colleagues from the United States, Romania, Hungary, and Italy will renew archaeological excavations at the site of Pecica "ªanþul Mare" in southwestern Romania. The great tell of Pecica "ªanþul Mare" is among the most important Bronze Age sites in Europe, and was a major center for the production and trade of bronze tools, ornaments and weapons. Previous National Science Foundation supported research has shown that Pecica was a complex polity with centralized public architecture, craft specialists, and segregated social strata. The research also demonstrated that Pecica was deeply involved in the spread of domestic horses, and possibly also chariots, into Europe. While this prior work presented a picture of Pecica at its peak, and of its rapid collapse, the present research effort is concerned with understanding how Pecica rose to prominence.

The remaining archaeological layers at Pecica hold a unique record of the internal and external factors which brought the Pecica society into existence. The excavations will provide a detailed view of the emergence of Pecica as a major regional center and clarify the context of this development, both among the contemporary local communities and within the larger regional networks of the European Bronze Age. The research will contribute to our understanding of how social inequality and complexity develop, and highlight a form of societal organization that is central to cultural developments in the European Bronze Age but which may differ from the complex chiefdom type organization seen in other parts of the World. The excavation will generate important new information relating to the development and organization of metallurgy and craft production, and provide critical evidence relating to the Bronze Age subsistence and productive economies, and particularly to the transformative spread of the domestic horse and associated transport technologies into Europe. Finally, the excavations will provide a complete record of not only the material culture of this important EU Cultural Heritage site, but also of the Bronze Age climate and environment, and particularly the cultural impacts of Pecica's development on the local and regional environment that may be linked to significant environmental deteriorations at the end of the Middle Bronze Age.

Apart from understanding the settlement of Pecica, itself, the research promises a number of broader benefits. The work at Pecica will contribute to the larger research effort in the Carpathian Basin Bronze Age. Concurrent research projects in Hungary, Romania, and Serbia are combining to provide a macro-regional dataset for archaeological research that is unique in Europe and may rival places such as the Valley of Mexico or Oaxaca as a laboratory for the study of culture change. The research provides international research experience for American graduate and undergraduate students, and provides training opportunities for beginning and advanced Romanian students. The collaborative and interdisciplinary effort provides training benefits to all participants, senior and junior alike, and is supporting innovations in research design and excavation strategies within Romania. The project is also contributing to the infrastructure of archaeological research by providing improved curation and access for the archaeological collections from this important site.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pecica ?an?ul Mare is a Bronze Age archaeological site in western Romania that was occupied between 1950 and 1600 BC.  During this time, the site rose to become one of the most important Bronze Age centers in Eastern Europe.  Previous National Science Foundation funded research documented the site at its peak.  During this time, the settlement was intensively engaged in the production of bronze weaponry and personal ornaments and was the primary center for the trade of domestic horses into Europe.

              With this understanding of Pecica at its peak, the current National Science Foundation award was focused on how the site came into being, and how it rose to such prominence.  To do this, archaeological excavations were continued to the full base of the six meter deep (20 ft) deposit.  Many of these new findings were unexpected and significantly change our understanding of Bronze Age society.

              For example, the new excavations revealed that the earliest occupation at Pecica did not date to the Bronze Age, but rather to the Middle Copper Age.  This initial occupation lasted from 3935 to 3800 BC; leaving a gap of nearly a thousand years before the establishment of the Bronze Age settlement.

              The Bronze Age settlement at Pecica was founded around 1950 BC, and was a special place from its inception.  The Maros group, to which Pecica belonged culturally, had existed in the region for more than 500 years prior to this date and was at its point of maximum regional expansion.  Prior to occupation, the surface of the site was completely leveled, and the first structure was unlike any building seen before or after.  It was a small rectangular building with a cylindrical structure attached to it.  Excavation revealed that during construction, a series of stone axes and large pig mandibles were embedded in the building’s floor.  The pig mandibles are of particular interest as they were perforated to facilitate fastening to a mask or for handles.  It seems likely that this was a special ritual deposit and that the building itself was part of a foundational ritual associated with the establishment of the settlement.

              Once established, Pecica rapidly became a major center of international trade, not only in bronze weaponry, but also in elaborate head ornaments and regalia fashioned from highly polished animal teeth, amber from the Baltic, faience from the Levant, and exotic shells from the Mediterranean and Black Seas.  Yet despite all this activity, the site remained small and lacked fortification ditches or other defensive structures.

              Around 1850 BC the large encircling ditch was constructed and a new settlement plan was established which divided the site into an area of elite residence with a central plaza and an area of metallurgical production.  Horses at this time became a major focus of the elites.  By 1800 BC, most Bronze Age sites in the region were abandoned and their populations aggregated at Pecica.  This aggregation event saw the creation of several increasingly large encircling ditches, with settlement being accommodated within the bounds of these ditches.  On the central portion of the site, a large platform was created where the central plaza had been.  The platform was the site of elite display and feasting.  This was Pecica at its peak.

              Based on our new excavations, we now know that the site of Pecica ?an?ul Mare was established de novo, and that from its inception it was designed to be the main center for the developing Bronze Age society.  Yet despite this special status, the site remained relatively small for most of its history and relied on the ability of the elites to mobilize labor and resources from the surrounding Maros settlements.  The aggregation event observed around 1800 BC represented the critical point at which Pecica transitioned into a more complex, although short lived, polity. 

              The research at Pecica ?an?ul Mare has provided a unique and highly detailed case study for how complex, non-state societies developed and collapsed.  Since this is a process that cannot be observed in the present day or from historical sources, this account represents a contribution that can only be obtained through archaeology.  The results enhance the understanding of Europe’s early development and provide an important new comparative case for anthropology more broadly.  The project provided training and international research experience for a number of American undergraduate and graduate students (along with their Romanian and Hungarian counterparts) and provided collaborative linkages for American scholars wishing to work in Eastern Europe.  The curated records and collections represent a valuable asset for use by scholars in the future.
